Comment:
Hi everyone!

At last some happy news to post on another battle on the Expert's Playing Field - a draw game against my expert buddy Michael.  We did follow the World DB for most of the game - I deviated on move 23 to exchange down into an opposite bishop ending to give me the chance to play through an ending with an expert on a level playing field.  Michael thought it was a little too level and offered me a draw!  Although it would have been interesting to play it through I decided that the chance to obtain only my third Expert Draw in my chessic career was too good to pass up, especially given my atrocious record against the Experts.  Anyhow, on with the game, I decide to have another stab at the Reti Opening with 1. Nf3.
2. c4 - transposes the opening into an English Opening.
2. c4 - transposes the opening into an English Opening.
4. g3 - preparing to fianchetto Fou Leblanc on the long h1-a8 diagonal.
4. g3 - preparing to fianchetto Fou Leblanc on the long h1-a8 diagonal.
4. g3 - preparing to fianchetto Fou Leblanc on the long h1-a8 diagonal.
4. g3 - preparing to fianchetto Fou Leblanc on the long h1-a8 diagonal.
6. ....... Be7 - black clears the way to castle kingside, however, as you will see later on, his king will remain in the centre.
6. ....... Be7 - black clears the way to castle kingside, however, as you will see later on, his king will remain in the centre.
6. ....... Be7 - black clears the way to castle kingside, however, as you will see later on, his king will remain in the centre.
6. ....... Be7 - black clears the way to castle kingside, however, as you will see later on, his king will remain in the centre.
6. ....... Be7 - black clears the way to castle kingside, however, as you will see later on, his king will remain in the centre.
8. Qxd4 - pawn trade.
8. Qxd4 - pawn trade.
8. Qxd4 - pawn trade.
8. ...... d6 - preparing e5 perhaps?
9. Rd1 - puts pressure on the d6 pawn which although at the moment is guarded by the dsb it may well tie down that bishop to defending it!
10. b3 - solidifies c5.
10. b3 - solidifies c5.
11. e4 - increases control of d5.
11. e4 - increases control of d5.
12. Ba3 - the back row decks between the rooks are cleared.
12. Ba3 - the back row decks between the rooks are cleared.
14. Qxe5 - pawn trade - now the d file is opened.  A queen trade is on the cards.
14. Qxe5 - pawn trade - now the d file is opened.  A queen trade is on the cards.
14. Qxe5 - pawn trade - now the d file is opened.  A queen trade is on the cards.
14. Qxe5 - pawn trade - now the d file is opened.  A queen trade is on the cards.
15. ........ Rxc7 - the queen trade duly occurs.
15. ........ Rxc7 - the queen trade duly occurs.
15. ........ Rxc7 - the queen trade duly occurs.
16. Bc1 - Fou Lenoir undevelops but heads for f4.  Before that happens we have a knight trade.
18. Bf4 - attacks c7 rook.
18. Bf4 - attacks c7 rook.
18. Bf4 - attacks c7 rook.
18. Bf4 - attacks c7 rook.
19. Bd6 - now a bishop trade is on the cards.
19. Bd6 - now a bishop trade is on the cards.
20.  Bxc5 - but a bishop for knight trade occurs instead.
20.  Bxc5 - but a bishop for knight trade occurs instead.
20.  Bxc5 - but a bishop for knight trade occurs instead.
22. Bxf3 - another B for N trade occurs.  Suddenly we have opposite colour bishops.  Michael defends the e6 pawn by moving his king.
22. Bxf3 - another B for N trade occurs.  Suddenly we have opposite colour bishops.  Michael defends the e6 pawn by moving his king.
22. Bxf3 - another B for N trade occurs.  Suddenly we have opposite colour bishops.  Michael defends the e6 pawn by moving his king.

23. Rad1 - in the World DB white played Bb7.  I analysed that taking the a6 pawn after a Rb8 move, say, would have allowed Fou Leblanc to be skewered against my a2 pawn allowing a Bone in the Throat.  I decide to force a trade down to an opposite colour bishops ending.  Black must trade or allow me to monopolise the d file.

23. Rad1 - in the World DB white played Bb7.  I analysed that taking the a6 pawn after a Rb8 move, say, would have allowed Fou Leblanc to be skewered against my a2 pawn allowing a Bone in the Throat.  I decide to force a trade down to an opposite colour bishops ending.  Black must trade or allow me to monopolise the d file.

25. ........ Rxd1+ and DRAW OFFER!  Despite the difference in our ratings and despite the fact that I had previously lost 5 out of my 6 games with him he did not wish to play out the ending.  I thought that he would given the fact that his king was more centralised than Henry but he didn't.  Michael is still winning overall - by 5.5 points to 1 in our 7 game encounters.  Still, after the recent horror show against Master Freddy I am only too pleased to have something like this to write home about.
